author: All images courtesy of the Folio Society and the House of Illustration
title: Illustrating Jane Austen's Mansfield Park – in pictures | Books
text:
Illustrating Jane Austen's Mansfield Park – in pictures Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share via Email View more sharing options Share on LinkedIn Share on Pinterest Share on Google+ Share on WhatsApp Share on Messenger Close 
Here are the 23 competition finalists in the running to illustrate the Folio Society’s new edition of the classic story of Fanny Price. The winner will be announced on 23 February
All images courtesy of the Folio Society and the House of Illustration
Wednesday 1 February 2017 12.49 GMT 
Marsha Balaeva, UK 
‘Afraid of everybody, ashamed of herself and longing for the home she had left, she knew not to look up and could scarcely speak to be heard, or without crying.’ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Rose Bowskill, UK (student) 
‘The grandeur of the house astonished, but could not console her. The rooms were too large for her to move in with ease; whatever she touched she expected to injure, and she crept about in constant terror of something or other.’ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Janelle Carbajal, USA 
‘As far as she could judge, Mr Crawford was considerably the best actor of all.’ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Jessica Cho, USA 
‘The smallness of the house and thinness of the walls brought everything so close … “What have you got there?”… It was a silver knife.’ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Nora Dåsnes, Norway (student) 
‘She was a great deal too much frightened to have any enjoyment, till she could suppose herself no longer looked at.’ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Louise Fricker, UK 
‘I am to have it to-morrow; but how do you think it is to be conveyed? Not by waggon or cart; - Oh!’ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Marianna Gefen, Russia 
‘When she did understand it, however, and found herself expected to believe that she had created sensations which his heart had never known before …’ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Winwen Hu, Taiwan 
‘She watched them till they had turned the corner, and listened till all sound of them had ceased.’ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Nataša Ilinčić, Italy 
‘... and sleep seeming to be her likeliest friend, she was taken to finish her sorrows in bed.’ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Julie Konieczna, Poland 
‘You must think of Henry, for it was his choice in the first place.’ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Kathrin Lang, Germany 
‘The misery of the girl when he left her.’ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Rachael Lovatt, UK 
‘When I look out on such a night as this, I feel as if there could be neither wickedness or sorrow in the world’ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Bistra Masseva, Bulgaria 
‘Here everybody was noisy, every voice was loud.’ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Marta Pantaleo, Italy 
‘I sat three quarters of an hour in the flower garden, while Fanny cut the roses, and very pleasant it was I assure you, but very hot.’ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Katie Ponder, UK 
‘Nobody meant to be unkind, but nobody put themselves out of their way to secure her comfort.’ Photograph: Folio Society / House of Illustration
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Alexandru Savescu, UK 
‘It was a sound which did not make her cheerful; she wondered that Edmund should forget her, and felt a pang.’ Photograph: Folio Society / House of Illustration
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Anna Severynovska, Germany 
‘… she fancied him sitting in that room … listening with constant delight to the favourite air … played … with superior tone and expression.’ Photograph: Folio Society / House of Illustration
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Darya Shnykina, Russia (student) 
‘“I hope she will not tease my poor pug,” said Lady Bertram; “I have but just got Julia to leave it alone.”’ Photograph: Folio Society / House of Illustration
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Pedro Silmon, UK 
‘... she found herself... conducted by Mr Crawford to the top of the room … to be joined by the rest of the dancers, couple after couple.’ Photograph: Folio Society / House of Illustration
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Wen Dee Tan, Malaysia 
‘To prompt them must be enough for her; and it was sometimes more than enough; for she could not always pay attention to the book.’ Photograph: Folio Society / House of Illustration
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Sophia Watts, UK (student) 
‘A young woman, pretty, lively, with a harp as elegant as herself, and both placed near a window, cut down to the ground.’ Photograph: Folio Society / House of Illustration
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Amree Weaver, UK 
‘Susan had read nothing and Fanny longed to give her a share in her own first pleasures.’ Photograph: Folio Society / House of Illustration
Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Meizhen Xu, UK (student) 
‘It was Fanny’s first ball, though without the preparation or splendour of many a young lady’s first ball.’ Photograph: Folio Society / House of Illustration
Facebook Twitter Pinterest
